name.text: Application of reciprocals - period of a pendulum

questiontext.text:
The period (\(T\)) of a swinging pendulum is the reciprocal of its frequency (\(f\)). The relationship is given by the formula:

\(T = \frac{1}{f} \)

A digital sensor records the frequency of a pendulum as {@freq_disp@} Hz.

Use a table of reciprocals to calculate the period of the pendulum in seconds.

Period (\(T\)) \(=\) [[input:ans1]] s [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

To find the period, we need to find the reciprocal of \({@freq_disp@}\).

\[ T = \frac{1}{{@freq_disp@}} \]

Using a mathematical table of reciprocals:

1. Move down the column labelled \(x\) to the row {@part_a@}.

2. Move across to the main column headed {@part_b@}.
The value at this intersection is {@table_val_main@}.

3. Continue along the same row to the "SUBTRACT" (Mean Difference) column headed {@part_c@}.
The mean difference value found here corresponds to {@sub_num@} (representing 0.000{@sub_num@}).

4. Subtract the mean difference from the main table value.
(We subtract because the function \(y=1/x\) is a decreasing function).

\[ {@table_val_main@} - 0.000{@sub_num@} = {@ta@} \]

The period of the pendulum is {@ta@} seconds.

Sheila Cherotich

This question requires the learner to find the reciprocal of a given decimal number using a table.
